title: Nerf ALL damage done by champions with 10%
body:
Literally everything that makes champs deal more damage.

Their base AD, attack speed, stats and damage granted by items, AD and AP ratios. Literally ALL damage done by champs, and keep the damage monsters, minions and turrets deals.

Try this out for at least one patch, and if it doesn't solve any problems, just revert it.

The damage IS way too high atm. It's a game of "who can oneshot the other faster", rather than "use your brain" like it was back in Season 1 when I started playing. I don't feel "outplayed" when an enemy with 1 more kill oneshots me. It just feels frustrating.

Pretty much no champion deals too much damage.  If you are in the middle of the enemy team and not a Vanguard tank initiating a fight, then you are in the wrong place and will be blown up.  You cannot just set yourself up for an all-in from the enemy mage, let the enemy marksman free-fire, and expect to survive.  Those players, and especially the marksman, spent the past twenty or thirty minutes carefully farming their kit.  This is their time now.

A more logical decision would be to buff the base armour and magic resist by ~10, or whatever the old runes gave.  Eliminating those invisible sources of stats is what first caused the damage spike, or at least made it noticeable.  It was surprising how important those relatively minor stats actually affected balanced.

This is where the new runes system has failed, imo.  Think of old runes: reds affected damage, yellows defence, blues for magic/ability, and glyphs were an extra boost to any one thing.  The new 'runes' (which are really masteries, idk why they called them runes) don't follow this at all.  Imagine if instead of the trees we have now, we were given a similar choice:

1. Pick one damage modifyer: damage, attack speed, penetration, etc.
2. Pick one defence modifyer: armour, HP, regen, etc.
3. Pick one ability modifyer: magic resist, mana regen, CDR, etc.
4. For glyphs, they could be the same as before (pick one stat to give a bigger boost), or they could be the keystone.  This would make more sense, as it would then more truly combine runes and masteries in one tree.

They could make this more sexy than just pure stat boosts.  They could implement the gathering storm idea, where you sacrifice early game stats for more late game.  You could do the opposite.  You could have stats tied to kills, to kda, to minions killed, to number of enemies nearby.  You still give players a chance to make the runes apply to their playstyle without introducing ridiculous things like Boneplate or Manaflow Band which is just the default choice for everyone.

It would be easier to balance, easier to understand, better able to adjust pre-match (similar to old runes, where you have a special armour page to use against assassins in lane, for example, whereas now you just go your default page most times) and put a serious dent on the early-game damage, which should reduce snowballing.  Doesn't solve the turret problems, but it's a start.

If all champions are hit with the same nerf, how can they become overpowered? If, for example, Cho'gath and Annie were fighting, and you suddenly nerfed both of their damage by 10%, why would either of them get an advantage out of it?
I ask because i've only been around since some time before the start of season 7, so I have never seen a tank meta.

Annie would suffer a lot from the 10% damage nerf. Her kit revolves arround oneshotting enemy champions. With 10% less damage this will be extremly difficult, even impossible. With her low range and squishiness playing annie would be a lot more difficult.

On the other side, cho gath is very tanky. Building tank items is a lot better, because their item efficiency is not reduced, whereas all ad/ap-items are 10% less efficient for the same price. Cho gath would be much harder to kill for a team, and he'd survive a lot longer in a teamfight and so he would do a lot more damage. Despite the 10% damage nerf. He can stay longer in a teamfight and do more attacks.

Yes you could argue that annie also survives longer because enemies do less damage, but this will probably not matter. After Annie flash tibbers and uses q and w, her spells are on cooldown. Even despite the enemies doing 10% less damage, they will still kill annie before her spells are off cooldown. In the time she survives longer she can do one auto attack at most.

If we only look at 1v1 annie and cho gath are not the best examples. Let's take leBlanc and jinx: In the current version leBlanc uses all her spells, jinx dies within 1 second. During this time jinx can attack once or twice. Leblanc looses half her hp. After 10% dmg nerfs, leblanc uses all her spells, but it's not enough to kill jinx. LeBlanc spells are all on cooldown, she can only auto attack for the next 5 seconds. Jinx kills leblanc after 3 seconds.

It's not so much a nerf to impact that early game/lane phase damage, it would be more impactful later on once team fights are starting.  If no one is getting one-shot any more, it means fights can last longer, which allows for more skill expression and macro play instead of just praying that your team has a marksman that can right click better.

Damage needs to be nerfed all around, but the right way to do it isn't something as straightforward as this. Nerfing everyone the same would make assassins and burst mages pretty bad while making dps'ers like adcs stronger by comparison. I agree damage needs to be lowered by a substantial amount, but it needs to be tuned properly.

I guess a way to do something straightforward like that without messing up the game for 1 patch is to make it a separate game mode. Maybe something like cutting all damage, sustain and shields in half and then checking the data to see what needs nerfs and what needs buffs.

i dont agree with this change but i do agree with the goal in mind, the current meta is doing way too much damage atm.

There are two possibilities i can think of that resulted in this:

1.) There was alot of discussion about game balance that came to the conclusion that buffing instead of nerfing to balance a game made it more exciting, and in a certain way it does, and i believe that Riot has actually taken this to account. 

OR, 

2.) There has been some power creep over the last couple of patches and metas that have gone unnoticed.


If it were the first point, meaning Riot has purposely focused on buffing champs, they need to realize that continually buffing will, yes make the game more "intense" and "exciting", but that will only become a case of URF; something that's intense and fun for the first few games but quickly wears down and, by Riot's own words, makes even long term players quit the game.

If it is the latter however, i would be rather disappointed that they haven't noticed such a change occurring so drastically. But if you think you can fix problemes like that, it's not going to work. A change like that would completly crush some champions. Champions, that can't deal with this change would go down to 20%- ish winrates, And bruiser type champions that do consistent damage thorughout fight would explode, achieving 80+% winrates.

If a 10% dmg-nerf across all champions was made and not reverted within one week the game would probably loose 80% of it's playerbase.

During last preseason they implemented a global buff along those lines to all damage. This'd be more of a reversion than anything. I mean, *potentially* for a **single** champion hyper buffed I could see it before it gets hotfixed, but if it's a dozen they'd run into each other and the win rates would equalize.
